WorkItem.Description:
In the tutorial (v3.0, page 46) is the name for the connectionstring "MovieDBContext".
This should be MusicStoreEntities then the right database is creaded / used.

Comments.Message: Yeah, thanks for posting this. Why it did not cause an exception, but rather returned 0 records is a bit worrisome.

I didn't think the name of the connection string was relevant. It's just a label. If the app only has one connection string defined, it will use it for DbContext.

That being said, it would be a bit more logical to name it MusicDBContext since this is a music store app.

The problem was that, after I had cteated the database, I could not locate it. (There was only one connectionstring in the config)
When debbuging I found that the database was created in .\SqlExpress so there was no error.

After changing the name of the connectionstring from MovieDBContext to MusicStoreEntities the database was created in the AppData directory :)
Thanks for reporting this. It's correct in the sample project, but wrong in the documentation. I appreciate your pointing it out!
I updated the PDF in this release.

FYI...I struggled with the connection string quite a bit, building/debugging after each change.  When I changed the name of the connection string to "MusicDBContext", it finally worked.  I can't explain why this made a difference because.  I have searched for another reference to this name in my entire solution and found none.  Here is my connection string:

<connectionStrings>
    <add name="MusicDBContext"
     connectionString="Data Source=.\SQLEXPRESS;Integrated Security=SSPI;AttachDBFilename=|DataDirectory|MvcMusicStore.mdf"
     providerName="System.Data.SQLClient"/>
  </connectionStrings>
